intro: Palicourea minarum, commonly known as the Peruvian moonflower, is a climbing shrub native to the Andean regions of South America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family, which includes over 13,000 species of flowering plants. The plant is characterized by its opposite, elliptical leaves and produces small, fragrant white flowers that bloom at night. Its fruit is a capsule that splits open to release tiny seeds. Palicourea minarum is also valued for its ornamental appeal and has been used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
